etymologies: early 19th century: from meta- (denoting a change of condition) + Greek morphē ‘form’+ -ic

definitions: denoting or relating to rock that has undergone transformation by heat, pressure, or other natural agencies, e.g. in the folding of strata or the nearby intrusion of igneous rocks
shortDefinitions: denoting or relating to rock that has undergone transformation by heat, pressure, or other natural agencies

examples.text: the shift from dead stillness to hurricane-force winds was as metamorphic as Jekyll to Hyde
